title: For, To, and So That | Grammar Exercise

questions.question: I talked to the shy girl ............................ she wouldn't feel left out.
questions.description: We use 'so' to indicate the result or effect.

questions.question: We stopped at the pub .............................. a drink.
questions.description: Only the infinitive can be used to express a person's purpose.

questions.question: We stopped at the pub ........................ a drink.
questions.description: 'For' can indicate purpose when it is followed by a noun. It cannot be used before a verb to express purpose.

questions.question: I went to Canada ............................ my brother.
questions.description: Only the infinitive can be used to express a person's purpose. 'For' can indicate it only when it is followed by a noun.

questions.question: What do I need to get ............................... dinner?
I took the phone back to the store ....................... a replacement.
questions.description: Only the infinitive can be used to express a person's purpose. 'For' can indicate it only when it is followed by a noun.

questions.question: We started early ........................... we wouldn't be late.
questions.description: In an informal style that can be dropped after so.

questions.question: You need to be over 18 ......................... that film.
questions.description: Only the infinitive can be used to express a person's purpose. 'For' can indicate it only when it is followed by a noun.

questions.question: I am leaving early today ........................... the rush hour traffic.
questions.description: Only the infinitive can be used to express a person's purpose. 'For' can indicate it only when it is followed by a noun.

questions.question: I am putting the meat in the oven now, .......................... it will be ready by eight o'clock.
questions.description: We use 'so that' before a clause to indicate purpose.

questions.question: I am angry with you ........................... me up.
questions.description: For can be followed by an ing form after a description of a reaction to explain the behavior that caused it.
